Title: Howl. The voice of a generation 
Original title: Howl 
Country: USA 
USA release: 24/09/2010 
Released in Spain: 25/03/2011 
Studio: WMA, Cinetic Media 
Director: Rob Epstein, Jeffrey Friedman 
Screenplay: Rob Epstein, Jeffrey Friedman 
Starring: James Franco, Mary-Louise Parker, Jon Hamm, Jeff Daniels, David Strathairn, Alessandro Nivola, Treat Williams, Bob Balaban, Aaron Tveit, Sean Patrick Reilly, Allen Ginsberg, Jon Prescott, Todd Rotondi, Cecilia Foss, Alex Emanuel 


Synopsis: 
Three intertwined stories: the development of a landmark obscenity trial in 1957, revelations of a rebellious artist breaks barriers for finding love, redemption and an imaginative journey through a prophetic masterpiece that rocked an entire generation in addition to create a multifaceted and multidisciplinary portrait of Howl (Howl), a work that was heard around the world. 

San Francisco in 1957, a masterpiece of American literature was brought to trial. The story unfolds from three intertwined threads: the trial, the hand of the young writer Allen Ginsberg (James Franco) and the poem itself, whose animation is provided by the graphic novelist and Ginsberg collaborator Eric Drooker, which shall conceived as a "fantasy beat", and whose music Carter Burwell has composed. The form "multidisciplinary" in which he develops the film is a reflection of the striking originality of the poem. 

The representation of the trial is a narrative into the fabric of a film which deals in place today, the definition of obscenity, the limits of freedom of expression and the nature of art. The young defense attorney Jake Ehrlich Allen (Jon Hamm), a celebrated champion of civil cases. The prosecutor, Ralph McIntosh (David Strathairn) tries to prove that the work is obscene as it strives to understand. The prosecution witnesses are a English teacher (Mary-Louise Parker) who considers the poem in question obscene and a college professor (Jeff Daniels) who has a very definite idea of ??what is and what is not good literature. The defense witnesses are intellectuals of the fifties (Treat Williams and Alessandro Nivola), who defend the cultural and artistic merit of the poem.
